intro: Arceuthobium campylopodum subsp. monticola, commonly known as the mountain dwarf broomrape, is a parasitic plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies entirely on its host for nutrients. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its small, yellowish stems and tiny, scale-like leaves. This species typically attaches to the roots of host plants such as grasses and forbs, forming a hemiparasitic relationship. It is native to mountainous regions of Europe and is often found in disturbed or open habitats. Due to its specialized lifestyle, it plays a unique role in the ecological dynamics of its environment.
